title: Quirky Serif Italic
content:
I'm trying to recreate this logo since this lo-res version won't work for my needs. Can anyone help me ID the font that was used?

Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317112116im_/http:/typophile.com/files/EphemeraSociety_5046.jpg)

Solved By: 

 [donshottype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317112116/http:/typophile.com/user/205259 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [EphemeraSociety.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317112116/http:/typophile.com/files/EphemeraSociety.jpg) | 3.54 KB |
author: chadkdesign

comments.content:
To me it looks more like a slightly pseudo-italicized Neuva by Adobe  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/nueva/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317112116/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/nueva/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/nueva/")

Technomage looks like a bad retracing of Nueva
I think Nueva was once available in a multiple master format. It's possible that the weight of the type in the logo was creating using the mm font.

Good find Josev.  
Neuva was available in a multiple master format in the 1990s but is now sold only as individual fonts. However, there are a large number of weights and several widths [http://www.fonts.com/font/adobe/nueva#product\_top](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317112116/http:/www.fonts.com/font/adobe/nueva#product_top "http://www.fonts.com/font/adobe/nueva#product\_top")  
Neueva includes true italics but they do not fit the logo.  
Here is Nueva Regular sloped 11 degrees

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317112116im_/http:/typophile.com/files/NuevaSloped11deg60pct_5948.jpg)
  
Compare to the italic 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317112116im_/http:/typophile.com/files/NuevaItalic60pct_5257.jpg)
  
Don
